Award.AwardTitle: Arctic Microbes: Population Abundance and the Effects of a Warming Environment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the research capacity at these institutions expands the opportunities for students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be locally relevant, and encourages a faculty community to look beyond the traditional classroom for intellectual and professional growth. This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will increase the body of knowledge on the impact of a warming environment on arctic microorganisms.

Ilisagvik College is the only U.S. college located in the Arctic at this time, which provides an advantageous location to collect data on microbial changes. Ilisagvik College will use DNA and RNA extractions from soil samples to test the hypothesis that temperature changes in the Arctic that affect microorganisms is followed by changes in arctic vegetation, which will ultimately affect arctic animals and the subsistence lifestyle of people in the Arctic. Undergraduate students will participate in fieldwork and sample collection, learn about genomics and gene sequencing, soil measurement techniques, and data analysis. In addition, students will experience communicating science at scientific conferences. There will be pre-college programming including presentations by the undergraduate researchers and summer camps on microbiology, where secondary students can learn about STEM careers and become involved with place-based research on topics that may affect their lives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Utqiaġvik (formerly known as Barrow), Alaska is a remote community only accessible by plane and 500 miles away from the nearest university. Located in the Arctic, Utqiaġvik is notable for climate change research. The emphasis of our project, "Arctic Microbes: Population abundance and the effects of a warming climate," is centered around microbes found in soil that could have impacts on both environmental and human health to include berry-producing plants and animals such as caribou that are important for the subsistence diet and health of many Alaska Natives. This project was designed to enhance the opportunities for underrepresented Iḷisaġvik tribal college undergraduate and pre-college students from rural communities on the North Slope of Alaska to be involved in a place-based research project while contributing to arctic climate research (Figure 1).

The objective of this project was to sequence DNA extracts to determine microbial species population types and abundance in soil samples collected from three layers of the Arctic tundra (vegetative layer, mineral layer, and the uppermost margin of the permafrost) (Figure 2). The following results are a fraction of the total bacterial reads and were of interest to the students. An ongoing analysis is currently being conducted.

Four bacterial species studied identified as Chthoniobacter flavus (C. flavus), Mycobacterium simulans (M. simulans), Clostridium alkalicellulosi (C. alkalicellulosi), and Clostridium histolyticum (C. histolyticum) may have environmental or human health impacts. C. flavus, a known soil microbe, has been indicated in the involvement of the carbon cycle.1 C. flavus could have huge impacts on overall soil health and environmental resilience to climate change.2

M. simulans (Table 1, Figure 3) is not a well-researched strain, but is potentially pathogenic. This species led to severe cavitary pulmonary disease being first diagnosed as multidrug resistant tuberculosis3 and later identified during treatment for confirmed antibiotic-resistant pulmonary tuberculosis.4 M. simulans is most abundant in the permafrost compared to the vegetative and mineral layers (Table 2).

C. alkalicellulosi, isolated in soil substrate from soda lakes in Buryatiya, Russia,5 are high in alkalinity and typically contain carbonate salts. Its ability to produce enzymes that break down cellulose in plants has raised the question if this species could be used to create biofuels.6 C. histolyticum occurs mostly in addicts that inject drugs. These infections cause abscesses to form at the site of injection and require surgery to be removed.7 The bacterium itself produces toxic enzymes that target muscle.8 Clostridium species have also been found in the human gut microbiota. People who suffer from Crohn's or irritable bowel disease have an imbalance of gut microbiota and have higher populations of C. histolyticum than those without the diseases.9 

These results are logged as a baseline study with future investigations to determine if there is correlation (if any) between changes of species types and abundance in Arctic soil that could have impacts on environmental and human health with the current trend of the warming Arctic.

References:

1. Swangwan, P., Chen, X., Hugenholtz, P., & Janssen, P.H. (2004). Chthoniobacter Flavus Gen. Nov., Sp. Nov., the First Pure-culture Representative of Subdivision Two, Spartobacteria Classis Nov., of the Phylum Verrucomicrobia. Applied & Environmental Microbiology, 70(10): 5875-81

2. Victora, R., Banwart, S.A., Black, H., Ingram, J., Joosten, H., Milne, E., & Noellemeyer, E. (2012). Benefits of soil carbon, Foresight Chapter in UNEP Yearbook 2012. United Nations Environment Programme: 19-33.

3. Tortoli, E., Rogasi, P.G., Fantoni, E., Beltrami, C., De Francisci, A., & Mariottini, A. (2010). Infection due to a novel mycobacterium, mimicking multidrug-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Clinical Microbiology & Infection, 14:1130-1134

4. Bouzid, F., Osman D. A., Baptiste E., Delerce J., Hassan M. O., Arreh W. I., Levasseur A., Garnotel, E., & Drancourt, M. (2018). Pulmonary Isolation of Multidrug Resistant Mycobacterium simulans and Mycobacterium tuberculosis from a patient in the Horn of Africa.? Scientific Reports, 8:15341

5. Zhilinal, T. N., Kevbrin, V. V., Tourova, T. P., Lyseenko, A. M., Kostrikina, N. A., & Zavarzin Winogradsky G. A. (2005). Clostridium alkalicellum sp. nov., an Obligately Alkaliphilic Cellulolytic Bacterium from a Soda Lake in the Baikal Region. Microbiology, 74: 557-566.

6 Phitsuwan, P., Morais, S., Dassa, B., Henrissat, B., & Bayer, E. A. (2019). The Cellulose Paradigm in An Extreme Alkaline Environment. Microorganisms, 7: 347.

7. Brazier, J. S., Gal, M., Hall, V., & Morris T. E. (2004). Outbreak of Clostridium histolyticum Infection in Injecting Drug Users in England and Scotland. Outbreak Report, 9(3): 15-16. 

8. Jozwiak, J., Grzela, T., Jankowska-Stiefer, E., Komar, A., Moskalewski, S. & Martirosian, G. (2007). Lethal factor of Clostridium histolyticum kills cells by apoptosis. FEMS Immunology & Medical Microbiology, 40(2): 296-303. 

9. Kleeseen, B., Kroesen, A. J., Buhr, H. J. & Blaut, M. (2002). Mucosal and Invading Bacteria Patients With Inflammatory Bowel Disease Compared With Controls. Scandinavian Journal of Gastroenterology, 37(9): 1034-1041.

    Unknown
    Linda Nicholas-Figueroa
    Students presenting at the 2019 ASM conference
  • Figure 2. Soil samples from vegetative layer (2 cm depth), mineral layer (10 cm depth), and upper most margin of the permafrost were taken from the Barrow Environmental Observatory, Utqiagvik (formerly known as Barrow), AK. From left to right: Rebekah Hare, Joanna Green, Linda Nicholas-Figueroa
    Michael Thomas
    Public Domain
    Linda Nicholas-Figueroa
    Soil collection from Arctic tundra.
  • Figure 3. Mycobacterium simulans percent abundance is higher compared to other species found in the permafrost layer taken on October 15, 2015. Note: The "Other" category in this pie chart is the sum of all classifications with less than 3.50% abundance.
    Illumina
    Public Domain
    Linda Nicholas-Figueroa
    M. simulans percent abundance taken from permafrost compared to other and unclassified species.
  • Table 1: Permafrost layer, October 15, 2015. Total species-level taxonomic categories identified: 842 classifications ae shown. Mycobacterium simulans total reads of 4.29% ranks number 1 of 8.
    Illumina
    Linda Nicholas-Figueroa
    M. simulans percent abundance taken from permafrost is number one in total reads out of 842 species.
  • Table 2. Mycobacterium simulans. Number of hits in permafrost layer is significantly higher than in the vegetative and mineral layers. Number of hits is 1000 or greater.
    Illumina
    Linda Nicholas-Figueroa
    Number of M. simulans hits between vegetative, mineral, and permafrost layers.
